Every so often I hear or read a term in the news and think "thats a clever use of language to dress up actual meaning". Collateral damage, friendly fire and pre-owned are some good examples of this sort of linguistical window dressing that seems to become ever more common place in the world today- so much so we even have a term for it- doublespeak.
 
 Which brings me to the topic of this thread; rendition (also known as extraordinary rendition), the most impressive example I have come across recently of the use of a word to obscure the actual reality of the practice it refers to.
 
 For those of you who are unfamiliar, here is the OccamsRazor guide to rendition. Lets say a state captures an individual who is suspected of involvement in organsied terrorist activity against it. That person is then subjected to the laws that country has regarding the treatment of those it holds in custody. In the case of Western countries like the one I live in that grants them certain rights with regard to how they can be treated and interrogated. The prisoner will be generally be protected from serious physical and mental torture, in accordance with international treaty.
 
 This acknowledgment of what is acceptable treatment also puts a limit on the methods that can be employed to extract information from the suspect. They could be in possession of information that if known to the state could prevent the loss of life through a terrorist attack. The suspect (lets assume they are a member of a terrorist organisation and are in possession of such information) is extremely motivatied for their cause and quite resistant to the methods of interrogation available to the state.
 
 However, there is another state who does not put such restaint on the treatment of those in the custody of its judical system and allows the practice of more extreme physical and mental methods on its prisoners- what most of us would refer to as torture. This state is willing to interrogate the Western state's prisoner using such methods in exchange for concession on other international issues.
 
 The Western state then sends its vital prisoner to the other state where they are interrogated and tortured to find all information they know. The information that is gained is then sent to the Western nation who knows there prisoner has been subjected to as harsh a questioning as is possible.
 
 The prisoner in effect disappears, if their existence is revealed in the first place at all.
 
 
 So is the practice of rendition acceptable? It provides a useful way to circumvent international treaties that states have signed up- we cannot torture this prisoner, but we think we need to- you can do it for us, thankyou.
 
 Is information gained through the torture of prisoners reliable?
 
 Should states allow favour to those who are prepared to torture their prisoners on other matters of international law and compliance?
 
 Can rendition be justified bearing in mind the ruthless nature of the struggle against organised international terrorist activity?
 
 I'm most interested to hear views on this matter.
